Award.AwardTitle: Attendance at Annual CBET Grantee Conference, Baltimore, Maryland, June 6 - 8, 2012

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1246788
Alison M. Cupples
Michigan State University

This is a travel grant for the CBET grantee to attend and present at the CBET Grantee Conference in Baltimore, June 6-8, 2012

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant was provided to attend the Annual CBET Grantee Conference, Baltimore, Maryland, June 6 - 8, 2012. At this conference, research funded by the NSF Grant 0853249, entitled “Stable Isotope Probing to Assess Bioremediation of LUST Contaminants: Addressing Existing MTBE/BTEX and Probable Future Ethanol/BTEX Contamination” was presented by the PI. Attendance at this conference enabled the PI to build collaborative relationships within the community of CBET grantees and Program Directors. The overall objective of the research presented is to identify the microbes and functional genes responsible for the degradation of contaminants associated with gasoline spills, such as benzene, toluene, xylene and ethylbenzene (BTEX) and methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE) using stable isotope probing (SIP). The effect of isobutanol (replacement for ethanol as a gasoline additive) on BTEX degradation rates is also being investigated. To date, the research has support three graduate students and one undergraduate student. Three of these students are underrepresented in environmental engineering.

To date, the project has focused on the following specific objectives 1) to apply SIP to identify novel anaerobic toluene degrading microorganisms across a range of environmental samples, 2) to examine the diversity in functional genes for anaerobic toluene degradation (bssA and bamA) across a range of redox conditions and inoculum sources, 3) to apply SIP to identify anaerobic MTBE degrading microorganisms, 4) to examine the effect of isobutanol on anaerobic toluene degradation rates and 5) to apply SIP to identify ethylbenzene degrading microorganisms. The project has also involved outreach to K-12 students through various programs within the College of Engineering.


Last Modified: 01/09/2013
Modified by: Alison M Cupples
